bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J. F. Siler, December 19, 1946

div1.p: Hench sends Siler photographs of the recent Walter Reed Memorial Association board meeting and poses questions related to his research on the yellow fever experiments. He offers his opinion of George Carroll.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J. F. Siler, December 19, 1946
div1.opener:
December 19, 1946
Colonel J. F. Siler, Secretary
WALTER REED MEMORIAL ASSOCIATION
3434--34th Place, North West
Washington, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
By separate post I have sent you some enlargements of the
small snapshots which I took on the occasion of our recent meeting.
I have sent similar enlargements, not only to the other men in the
photographs, but also to Mrs. Walter Reed and Blossom and to General
and Mrs. Reed.

p.del:
If you think that the other Members of the Board who were
not there would like copies, I will send them small contact prints.
I don't suppose they will particularly care to have enlargements. If
you wish me to do this, please send me the addresses of General Reynolds
and General Keefer. I have Doctor Howard's address.

I thoroughly enjoyed the meeting. I have been so very busy
since returning that I haven't yet had a chance to type up an abstract
of the remarks I made but I will do so in the very near future. Would
one copy for you be sufficient or would you like to have me send you
eight or nine copies? We could make that many (but not more) on the
first run if we use onion-skin paper. Please accept my sincere
Christmas greetings.

closer.seg:
P. S. Please don't judge these little enlargements in the light of
a professional job. I took them with a little $5 “flash” Brownie.
Colonel Siler, do you know any one still living who heard
Walter Reed give his first paper at Indianapolis? I am so anxious to
find someone. General Truby recently told me about Doctor Ravanel
who had been there. I wrote him but most unfortunately he had just
died a short time before.
Did you ever know of, or see, or hear of General Sternberg's
written instructions to Reed in connection with the formation of the
Colonel J. F. Siler, Secretary
-2-
December 19, 1946
Yellow Fever Board? I have never seen them in the National Archives
Building--I have poured over hundreds of documents and never came
across that; however, in the biography of Sternberg, written by his
wife, some remarks of Sternberg are published in which he mentions
written instructions to Reed. Elsewhere Agramonte spoke of Sternberg's
verbal instructions to Reed. Of course, I have the Order creating the
Board but this contains nothing comparable to what Sternberg says he
wrote to Reed. General Kean never heard of any written instructions
to Reed. If such were given, it is a mystery to me why I can't locate
them.
In Washington I tried to get in touch with Colonel La Garde.
He was not in the Pentagon Building when I was there but I had a very
nice telephone conversation with him. He told me that he hadn't seen
George Carroll since the latter was a boy and he has had no contact
with the Carroll family for many many years. He was afraid, therefore,
that he could not help me out.
I went to see Mr. L. E. Reed (no relation) again--he was
Sergeant Tracy's son-in-law and I had seen him in May, 1946. Mr. Reed
had tried to contact Carroll on a couple occasions but Carroll had
proved just as elusive to him as he had to me. On one occasion Carroll
did not even let him come inside the house. Mr. Reed probably omitted
any mention of me and my interest and approached Carroll with the idea
that he, Reed, wanted to write up a little story about his father-in-
law, Mr. Tracy. Mr. Reed told me that frankly he thinks George Carroll
is “crazy.” I heartily agree.
I wrote down Colonel La Garde's address on a piece of hotel
stationery but for the life of me since my return I have been unable
to find it. It will turn up in due time; but, in the meantime, will
you kindly send me his initials so that I may write him.
